metadata.subject: When It Comes to Wall Street, Preet Bharara Is No Hero - ProPublica

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

relationships.description: Trump fired Bharara as U.S. Attorney
Cohn was a mentor and lawyer for young Donald Trump

analysis.purpose: To share critical analysis of Preet Bharara's prosecutorial record regarding Wall Street
analysis.significance: High-level communication sharing critical media analysis of a prominent former U.S. Attorney's handling of financial crisis cases

notable_quotes: "How do you justify prosecuting a nineteen-year old who sells drugs on a street corner when you say it's too complicated to go after the people who move the money?" - Robert Morgenthau

"Bharara missed an opportunity by not bringing any significant criminal charges against individuals in the wake of the collapses of Lehman, investment bank Merrill Lynch, the insurer AIG, the mortgage securities and collateralized debt obligation businesses"
"Bharara's office brought one case for misconduct during the financial crisis - against a mid-level banker"

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found - this is straightforward sharing of a news article

illegal_activity.description: Document shares a ProPublica news article analyzing Preet Bharara's prosecutorial record - no first-hand illegal activity discussed

details: Media analysis of Preet Bharara's record
References to press conferences and media strategy

public_knowledge.context: This is a published ProPublica article about a high-profile U.S. Attorney's record that was widely covered in media

analysis.summary: Kathy Ruemmler forwards a ProPublica article to Jeffrey E. that critically analyzes Preet Bharara's tenure as U.S. Attorney, highlighting his aggressive prosecution of political corruption cases while questioning his reluctance to pursue senior Wall Street executives for financial crisis misconduct.
